3.(J) Whoever unlawfully and intentionally seizes or exercises control of an airerat in
service by force or threat thereof, or by coercion, or by any other form of intimidation, or by
any technological means, commits the offence of hijacking.

(2)Aperson shall also be deemed to have committed the offence of hijacking specified
in sub-section (1), if, such person—

(@) makes a threat to commit such offence or unlawfully and intentionally causes
any person to receive such threat under circumstances which indicate that the threat
is credible; or

(®) attempts to commit or abets the commission of such offence; or

(©) organises or directs others to commit such offence or the offence specified
in clause (a) or clause (b) above;

(@) participates as an accomplice in such offence or the offence specified in
clause (a) or clause (b) above;

(©) unlawfully and intentionally assists another person to evade investigation,
prosecution or punishment, knowing that such person has committed any such offence
or the offence specified in clause (a) or clause (b) or clause (c) or clause (d) above, or
that such person is wanted for criminal prosecution by law enforcement authorities for
such an offence or has been sentenced for such an offence,

(3) A person also commits the offence of hijacking, when committed intentionally
whether or not any of the offences specified in sub-section (1) or in clause (a) of
sub-section (2) is actually committed or attempted, either or both of the following —
(a) agreeing with one or more other persons to commit an offence specified in
sub-section (J) or in clause (a) of sub-section (2), involving an act undertaken by one
‘of the participants in furtherance of the agreement; or
(®) contributing in any manner to the commission of an offence specified in
sub-section (J) or in clause (a) of sub-section (2) by a group of persons acting with a
‘common purpose and such contribution shall either—
(be made with the aim of furthering the general criminal activity or purpose
of the group, where such activity or purpose involves the commission of such
an offence; or

(ii) be made in the knowledge of the intention ofthe group to commit such
offence.

(4) For the purposes of this Act, an aircraft shall be considered to be “in service’
the beginning of the pre-flight preparation of the aircraft by ground personnel or by the crew
for a specific flight until twenty-four hours after any landing and in the case of a forced
landing, the flight shall be deemed to continue until the competent authorities take over the
responsibility for the aircraft and for persons and property on board

Whoever commits the offence of hijacking shall be punished—
(@) with death where such offence results in the death of a hostage or of a
security personnel or of any person not involved in the offence, asa direct consequence
of the office of hijacking; or
(® with imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder
of that person's natural life and with fine,
